tabs.header_iregular:
Hives is pretty common and mild cases usually go away on its own.

The goal of over the counter medications in the management of hives are

  • to stop the histamine that is being released,
  • help with itching of any,
  • and soothe the skin if this hives is due to a dry skin.

With this in mind, see what is available over the counter for hives below.

collapsable.title: Antihistamine click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Content

collapsable.title: Anti itch lotions click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Content

collapsable.title: Worth doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Content

collapsable.title: Contacting the pharmacist click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You may have to unlock the contact form using social networking tools (facebook, twitter, google+, linkedIn) we have made available to you.

If you can't do this, you will have to wait a few seconds depending on the number of users at the time.

collapsable.title: What to expect click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Expect a reply as soon as possible.
If the authoring pharmacist cannot reply within 24 hours, the system will push your email to the rest of the team. Any available pharmacist will answer your question as soon as possible.

If you have a comment and not a question, please post it in the comments section for all to read.

collapsable.title: What can't be done: click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
No replies to vulgar, disrespectful emails.
The system is programmed to look for certain words that are disrespectful and will automatically delete such emails. They don't get to the pharmacist. This will blacklist your email address automatically.

Email addresses or questions are not saved.
They are deleted once answered and not stored in a database. Should you need to follow up, copy the previous question(s) along with the new message for quick reference.

The pharmacist does not reply to emails that are not relevant to the topic he or she authored. They are forwarded to the author of the topic and are under no obligation to reply.

We encourage pharmacists to respond to questions but are under no obligations to answer questions.

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's see what is available over-the-counter to take care of this ringworm.

Basically, ringworm is a fungal infection and to treat it would require an antifungal cream.

The question we will take a look at is which would work better for you? How should you use it? How long?

With these questions in mind, see what is recommended below.

collapsable.title: Anti-fungal click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Apply this to the affected area including up to an inch of the surrounding normal skin.

There are different ingredients of over-the-counter antifungal creams, here are the pros and cons of each.

Terbinafine

  • Pros:
    --- Faster result
    --- Penetrates deeper into hair follicles, so prefer this if affected area is hairy
    --- First choice - if cost is not a problem.
  • Cons:
    --- About $2 more expensive than others

Clotrimazole

  • Pros:
    --- Equally effective as terbinafine.
    --- Cheaper than the others
  • Cons:
    --- Takes a bit longer to clear the infection  

Miconazole

  • Pros:
    --- Comparable to clotrimazole.
  • Cons:
    --- A bit longer to clear the infection 

Butenafine

  • Pros:
    --- Comparable to terbinafine.
    --- Butenafine and terbinafine slightly more effective than others.
  • Cons:
    --- Cost 

Blue star ointment

  • Pros:
    Faster for itching.
  • Cons:
    --- Not antifungal
    --- Will not cure the infection.
    --- For itching only.

collapsable.title: Anti-inflammatory click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
If the affected area is inflamed, add hydrocortisone 1% cream.

Hydrocortisone reduces inflammation and ease the itching and redness quicker.

But do not use for more than 7 days.

Continue using the anti fungal cream alone after 7 days.

collapsable.title: Worth doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Content like natural meds, cleaning and so on.

Reduce moisture in affected area.

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 08/26/2015

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's see what is available for wart over-the-counter.

Before you apply any wart medications, you have to file  the wart with a nail file or emery board when your skin is damp (after a shower or bath). Otherwise they would not work.

Your main goal should be to remove the warts without any scarring.

With this in mind, see what is recommended for wart removal over the counter below.

collapsable.title: Salicylic acid click to expand contents
collapsable.content: content

collapsable.title: Freezing click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Content

collapsable.title: Worth doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Combining both methods above for large warts

tabs.header_iregular:
This recommendation assumes you are looking at a minor sprain.

There is nothing like it is just a sprain. You have to take this seriously. 

What to remember is that for the first 48 to 72 hours you have to pay the PRICE (Protect, Rest, Ice, Compress, Elevate) and do no HARM (no Heat, Alcohol, Running, Massage).

That should be easy to remember. See what is recommended using this approach and which over the counter pain medications to use below.

collapsable.title: Paying the PRICE click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
First 48 to 72 hours:    

 Protect the ankle from further injury. Use an ankle brace or elastic ACE bandage. 


 If you have to get to the pharmacy to get these things, try wearing a boot with high sides or lace-up shoe to give the protection the ankle need.
            
  Rest the ankle.
You will need crutches if you decide to move around.
        
 Ice, ice and ice.
 Apply an ice pack for 10 to 30 minutes every 1 to 2 hours during the day.
Less than 10 minutes have little or no effect.
More than 30 minutes may be too long and can damage the skin. 
 Don't need to go to the pharmacy looking for ice bags. Grab a bag of peas from the freezer and put on it or get a ziplock bag, fill with water about 1/3 of the way, add about 5 to 7 cubes of ice and use as an ice bag. Or make an ice pack by wrapping ice cubes in a plastic bag or towel.
        
 Compression.
Use an elastic bandage for compression. This is to help reduce swelling, rest it and remind you of the injured ankle before you start trying to use it.
 Make sure it is not too tight. You want the blood to flow.
        
 Elevate.
Raise the ankle above the level of your heart for 2 to 3 hours a day to reduce swelling. 
Lie on a sofa and put your foot on some cushions, or  put your foot on a pillow while in bed.

collapsable.title: Do no Harm click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
First 48 to 72 hours:

No Heat.

Should be avoided when inflammation is forming as it increases blood flow to the area. 
Wait till after 72 hours when no inflammation is likely to develop before using heat to provide a soothing effect if you like.
            
No Alcohol.
Drinking alcohol can increase bleeding, swelling and decrease healing.
            
No Running.
Well, avoid this. Don't do it within the first 72 hours just because you can.
            
No Massage.
Wait till after about 72 hours. This can increase bleeding and swelling.
But may be soothing after 72 hours.

collapsable.title: OTC  medications click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Acetaminophen:

Take this to help with the pain within the first 24 to 48 hours.
 Do not use anti inflammatory pain relievers for the first 24 to 48 hours.
Let the body's natural inflammatory process kick in to improve healing and protect the surrounding tissues from this trauma.
            
NSAIDS:

Start this after 24 to 48 hours to reduce the swelling and stop the inflammation.

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 08/25/2015
